results.content:
Good at teaching but everything is JavaScript to start then once all the the work is done it the types get added. Coming from staticly typed languages, I'm used to using the types to figure it out rather than relying on watching the video to see what the properties of the <any> type is. Bit frustrating after sitting through all the boring stuff. 

The project is interesting but not what I was expecting with the title of the course. Gave up at at video 63.

results.content:
It's Stephen "The Diagram" Grider...I don't even have to watch to know it's 5 stars.

***Update***
I'm halfway through this course and it's looking like this is the best Stephen Grider course that I've taken.

1) The majority of the videos are 6 minutes or less, which creates amazing momentum so that it feels like you are falling through the course.

2) The sections are around an hour, which allows to complete 1 per sitdown in the evening, giving me a big dopamine hit and keeping me motivated to see the course through to the end.

3) Maybe some people don't like, but Stephen's style to a) telling you what he's going to tell you, b) tells you, c) tells you what he told you really helps me not miss things and to always feel like I know what's going on.

** Update Finished Course**

whew!! That was a beast. amazing course, wonderfully taught, & cool project. Buy it.

Great job man!

results.content: Stephen's courses just keep getting better; He was born to teach software engineering. His teaching style is brilliant. He doesn't just jump to the solution, he guides you step by step, revealing how you actually go from an idea, through design, proof of concept, then iterating through the development process and finishing with a beautifully elegant solution. He will take you through all the errors and mistakes you WILL make on your own in development, shows you how to diagnose, debug and fix each one so you do not experience it yourself in real life. He will take optional deep dives and completely geeks out on things and you walk away feeling smarter, like it was you that made the revelation.  I don't know what else to say. If you're on Udemy and do not buy ALL of Stephen's courses, you are wasting your time and money.
results.content_html: Stephen's courses just keep getting better; He was born to teach software engineering. His teaching style is brilliant. He doesn't just jump to the solution, he guides you step by step, revealing how you actually go from an idea, through design, proof of concept, then iterating through the development process and finishing with a beautifully elegant solution. He will take you through all the errors and mistakes you WILL make on your own in development, shows you how to diagnose, debug and fix each one so you do not experience it yourself in real life. He will take optional deep dives and completely geeks out on things and you walk away feeling smarter, like it was you that made the revelation. I don't know what else to say. If you're on Udemy and do not buy ALL of Stephen's courses, you are wasting your time and money.

results.content:
Stephen Grider  has consistently delivered  the ultimate learning experience in each of his courses I have subscribed to ,and is rightfully regarded as one of the best instructors at Udemy. For me , personally, he is the "go-to" course creator when modern JS ecosystem is involved.  

This course presents somewhat unorthodox project per Udemy standards - thankfully ! We get the opportunity to craft  a live code book/editor ,similar to CODEPEN, for instance. 
  
Every code line is clear ,every architectural decision is eloquently 
 discussed and explained , and is accompanied by insightful  visual diagrams to enhance the overall learning experience. 

Precision and coherency of those architectural discussions reveals  in-depth knowledge and first-hand experience  that Stephen has accumulated in the industry over the years.
 
To that end, a set of unique challenges awaits in this course , which presents an incredible value for money.
results.content_html:

Every code line is clear ,every architectural decision is eloquently
discussed and explained , and is accompanied by insightful visual diagrams to enhance the overall learning experience.

Precision and coherency of those architectural discussions reveals in-depth knowledge and first-hand experience that Stephen has accumulated in the industry over the years.

To that end, a set of unique challenges awaits in this course , which presents an incredible value for money.

results.content: Stephen is simply the best there is and he has outdone himself with this course. He somehow managed to come up with a complex application that 1) uses many lesser known apis and techniques (srcDocs? IndexDB?) 2) shows the decision making processes that necessitate these measures and 3) does so all the while managing to stay focused on the main thread of Typescripted Javascript.

He somehow managed to come up with a complex application that 1) uses many lesser known apis and techniques (srcDocs? IndexDB?) 2) shows the decision making processes that necessitate these measures and 3) does so all the while managing to stay focused on the main thread of Typescripted Javascript.

results.content:
A dedicated Typescript area is at the end of the course, which was really good and well explained. 
The rest of the course is very complicated with a bit of Typescript used but not very well explained why to use what we used.  It was more of a copy the code than understanding why we used what had we used in order to make Typescript work.
There were aspects that were interesting in this course especially how to deploy the app to npm and he seems really knowledgeable  and explains things in advance with diagrams, but somehow it all seemed still very complicated.

The course didn't even finish with the book.js (in the course notebook.js) output in a way shown as in the preview window. Instead it only shows json with a mention in the "Next steps" that we could figure it out ourselves. 

The answers to questions were all provided by students not by the instructor himself. So, it seems he doesn't really care. I really don't know where he got his high rankings from.
results.content_html:
A dedicated Typescript area is at the end of the course, which was really good and well explained.
The rest of the course is very complicated with a bit of Typescript used but not very well explained why to use what we used. It was more of a copy the code than understanding why we used what had we used in order to make Typescript work.
There were aspects that were interesting in this course especially how to deploy the app to npm and he seems really knowledgeable and explains things in advance with diagrams, but somehow it all seemed still very complicated.

The course didn't even finish with the book.js (in the course notebook.js) output in a way shown as in the preview window. Instead it only shows json with a mention in the "Next steps" that we could figure it out ourselves.

The answers to questions were all provided by students not by the instructor himself. So, it seems he doesn't really care. I really don't know where he got his high rankings from.

results.content: Its a good course, but I feel it needed a testing suite and some time of staging environment perhaps to ensure it would work in production.
results.content_html: Its a good course, but I feel it needed a testing suite and some time of staging environment perhaps to ensure it would work in production.

results.content:
This course suffers from a really glaring issue. It's called "React and Typescript: Build a Portfolio Project." Around the moment that Lerna is introduced, this project goes off the rails. At that point, we have a working React App that implements great features. It's in a perfect state to add to a portfolio website. Suddenly, we're hacking path into a CLI, running an Express server, and mutilating the core App to the point that it actually would take significant refactor to get it back into a state that is publishable online. No potential employer is going to download your npm package. They -MIGHT- click a link on portfolio website. As must be obvious by now, I was incredibly disappointed with the direction this course took at the end. Stephen out-scoped himself here with a twist at the end that he himself admitted was over-engineered. We're left with a random npm package in a sea of similar packages. Luckily, I saw this coming and was able to usher the code I'd written to that point off into another directory. Having now gotten through that last 10% of the course, I'm really glad I preserved the code in that state.

In terms of teaching, Grider is a great engineer-programmer, in that order. You look through a ton of diagrams, but he spends an inordinate amount of time at these diagrams repeating himself. Over and over. And over and over. And over and over. And over and over. Saying the same thing. Again and again. Again and again. Now imagine that over 8 minutes followed by a 6 minute video OF THE EXACT SAME THING. I understand that looking through diagrams and planning is helpful, but, after you've said something 3 times and had the diagram up on the screen for more than a minute, it's over. We get it. Anyone would. It's going to suddenly click better the 15th time you explain it. I'm sorry for the negativity, but the back 10% of this course really grinded my gears.
results.content_html:
This course suffers from a really glaring issue. It's called "React and Typescript: Build a Portfolio Project." Around the moment that Lerna is introduced, this project goes off the rails. At that point, we have a working React App that implements great features. It's in a perfect state to add to a portfolio website. Suddenly, we're hacking path into a CLI, running an Express server, and mutilating the core App to the point that it actually would take significant refactor to get it back into a state that is publishable online. No potential employer is going to download your npm package. They -MIGHT- click a link on portfolio website. As must be obvious by now, I was incredibly disappointed with the direction this course took at the end. Stephen out-scoped himself here with a twist at the end that he himself admitted was over-engineered. We're left with a random npm package in a sea of similar packages. Luckily, I saw this coming and was able to usher the code I'd written to that point off into another directory. Having now gotten through that last 10% of the course, I'm really glad I preserved the code in that state.

In terms of teaching, Grider is a great engineer-programmer, in that order. You look through a ton of diagrams, but he spends an inordinate amount of time at these diagrams repeating himself. Over and over. And over and over. And over and over. And over and over. Saying the same thing. Again and again. Again and again. Now imagine that over 8 minutes followed by a 6 minute video OF THE EXACT SAME THING. I understand that looking through diagrams and planning is helpful, but, after you've said something 3 times and had the diagram up on the screen for more than a minute, it's over. We get it. Anyone would. It's going to suddenly click better the 15th time you explain it. I'm sorry for the negativity, but the back 10% of this course really grinded my gears.

results.content:
Overall this is a great class from a great teacher, definitely worth the time!

The main problem this course has is that there are a ton of huge tangents.  The tangents are interesting and useful to know, but if you are trying to learn typescript/redux fast, just do the initial appendix and up to section 4.  If you have more time, up to section 20 of the project is worth it.  After that look ahead and see if the topics interest you bc he dives into less related material.
results.content_html:
Overall this is a great class from a great teacher, definitely worth the time!

The main problem this course has is that there are a ton of huge tangents. The tangents are interesting and useful to know, but if you are trying to learn typescript/redux fast, just do the initial appendix and up to section 4. If you have more time, up to section 20 of the project is worth it. After that look ahead and see if the topics interest you bc he dives into less related material.

results.content: What a terrific course! I am very impressed by the quality and thoughtfulness of the application that we were able to build throughout the lessons. It's a great course to bridge the gap between working on standard crud operations and engineering a software application for a real-world use case. The instructor did a phenomenal job in helping students to analyze the steps they need to take as an engineer and explaining the reason for our approaches to various design complications. I've learned a lot of practical knowledge that can now be applied to my other projects and I couldn't be happier about my decision to take this course.

The instructor did a phenomenal job in helping students to analyze the steps they need to take as an engineer and explaining the reason for our approaches to various design complications. I've learned a lot of practical knowledge that can now be applied to my other projects and I couldn't be happier about my decision to take this course.

results.content: So far this course has taught me a few things with using TypeScript with React. I am a React developer going on 4 years now but I struggle with some of the concepts that TypeScript brings to the table when using it with React. This course here is bridging that gap. If you are like me and struggling a little bit to connect the dots Stephen does a great job of explaining the concepts and giving insight as to why we do it a certain way.
results.content_html: So far this course has taught me a few things with using TypeScript with React. I am a React developer going on 4 years now but I struggle with some of the concepts that TypeScript brings to the table when using it with React. This course here is bridging that gap. If you are like me and struggling a little bit to connect the dots Stephen does a great job of explaining the concepts and giving insight as to why we do it a certain way.

results.content: The explanations are quite clear and pretty easy to follow through. It's not over bloated like other tutorials with too many videos and complex explanations, more direct to the point stuff. I also like how the course explains typescript and hooks. The narrator has an understanding demeanor, very clear speaking, communication which is a definite plus for me and a must on any tutorial. He's not too easy going and not too robotic like other tutorials like if they are reading the stuff off a book. Has a pretty good balanced narrative. The code is clear, easy to read, well separated components, easy to understand. I would recommend.

results.content:
This is the second course of S.G. that I am taking. He is one of go-to instructor on Udemy in my opinion. 
This course, like many courses in Udemy, it's a pretty decent course.
However, there are some things to mention about. #1. It'd be great if there is any explanation or at least some hints how we can implement the optional tasks at the very end. It felt like you just threw away what we almost finished and left. 
#2. instead of putting 5h 40min of TS course, it would be great if there's more about Lerna and general deployment in dept. There was only one deployment and that was it. Besides, it says TS part is optional, but I have to take all of it to get certificate.  #3. Error handlings (especially in try-catch) were very poorly dealt so it is hard to manage testing and so on.
I wrote quite a lot of complaints, but it was a 
great course for $10. Thank you S.G. for creating this course.
results.content_html:
This is the second course of S.G. that I am taking. He is one of go-to instructor on Udemy in my opinion.
This course, like many courses in Udemy, it's a pretty decent course.
However, there are some things to mention about. #1. It'd be great if there is any explanation or at least some hints how we can implement the optional tasks at the very end. It felt like you just threw away what we almost finished and left.
#2. instead of putting 5h 40min of TS course, it would be great if there's more about Lerna and general deployment in dept. There was only one deployment and that was it. Besides, it says TS part is optional, but I have to take all of it to get certificate. #3. Error handlings (especially in try-catch) were very poorly dealt so it is hard to manage testing and so on.
I wrote quite a lot of complaints, but it was a
great course for $10. Thank you S.G. for creating this course.

results.content: Stephen has implemented a course with great content and organization.  I really appreciate the primer he includes on TypeScript (an appendix) and his appropriately paced introductions to new topics.  If I have one criticism, it would be that there is no content on how to test any of the code, especially when it comes to the jbook application.  Given how much testing and TDD is emphasized by many employers, it seems like an oversight not to at least provide some sort of example on best practices for testing.  That said, this is not a course about testing and I understand that including it might be too big of an ask.  Great course overall!
results.content_html: Stephen has implemented a course with great content and organization. I really appreciate the primer he includes on TypeScript (an appendix) and his appropriately paced introductions to new topics. If I have one criticism, it would be that there is no content on how to test any of the code, especially when it comes to the jbook application. Given how much testing and TDD is emphasized by many employers, it seems like an oversight not to at least provide some sort of example on best practices for testing. That said, this is not a course about testing and I understand that including it might be too big of an ask. Great course overall!

results.content:
at first, i want to thanks Stephen for his passion of teaching so difficult topics and not giving up on challenging us to give our best to follow and understand what he want us to learn. The course is great and as always mind blowing :-) . You start excited , then you are frustrated with how long and how much commitment  you need to complete it. At the end you are just amazed with how much content you have received. 
again thank you for all. This was my 3rd course from him after the typescript and microservices the impression stay the same amazing content. Learning the hard way but learning the right things.
